sections.heading: What is CSS?
paragraphs: CSS stands for Cascading Style Sheets.
CSS is used to style and layout web pages.
It controls colors, fonts, spacing, and layout.

sections.heading: Why Use CSS?
paragraphs: CSS saves time by controlling multiple pages at once.
It improves website appearance.
It makes web pages responsive.

paragraphs: Flexbox is used to design flexible layouts.
It works in one dimension (row or column).

sections.heading: Grid System

It works with rows and columns.

sections.heading: Responsive Design
paragraphs: Media queries make websites responsive.

sections.heading: CSS Syntax
paragraphs: A CSS rule consists of a selector and a declaration block.
The selector points to the HTML element you want to style.
The declaration block contains one or more declarations separated by semicolons.
Each declaration includes a CSS property name and a value, separated by a colon.
Declaration blocks are surrounded by curly braces.

sections.heading: CSS Selectors
paragraphs: CSS selectors are used to select the HTML elements you want to style.
Selectors can target elements based on name, id, class, attributes, and relationships.
There are five main categories of CSS selectors.

sections.heading: Element Selector
paragraphs: The element selector selects HTML elements based on the element name.

sections.heading: ID Selector
paragraphs: The id selector uses the id attribute of an HTML element.
An id must be unique within a page.
sections.note: An id name cannot start with a number.

sections.heading: Class Selector
paragraphs: The class selector selects elements with a specific class.
Multiple elements can share the same class.

sections.heading: Multiple Classes
paragraphs: HTML elements can have more than one class.
sections.code: This paragraph uses two classes.

sections.heading: Universal Selector
paragraphs: The universal selector selects all elements on the page.

sections.heading: Grouping Selector
paragraphs: The grouping selector is used to apply the same style to multiple elements.
Selectors are separated by commas.

sections.heading: How to Add CSS
paragraphs: When a browser reads a style sheet, it will format the HTML document according to the information in the style sheet.
There are three ways of inserting a style sheet:
External CSS, Internal CSS, and Inline CSS.

sections.heading: External CSS
paragraphs: With an external style sheet, you can change the look of an entire website by changing just one file.
Each HTML page must include a reference to the external style sheet file inside the <link> element.
External style sheets must be saved with a .css extension.

sections.note: Inline styles should be used sparingly because they mix content with design.

sections.heading: Multiple Style Sheets
paragraphs: If multiple styles are defined for the same element, the last defined style will be applied.
This is based on the cascading order of CSS.

sections.heading: Cascading Order
paragraphs: When multiple styles apply to the same element, the following priority is used:
1. Inline style
2. External and internal styles
3. Browser default styles

sections.heading: CSS Comments
paragraphs: Comments are used to explain the CSS code and make it easier to understand.
They are also used to temporarily disable code.
Comments are ignored by browsers.

sections.heading: CSS Comment Syntax
paragraphs: A CSS comment starts with /* and ends with */.
CSS comments can be placed anywhere in the code.

sections.heading: Inline Comments
paragraphs: Comments can be placed at the end of a line.

sections.heading: Comments in the Middle of Code
paragraphs: Comments can also be written inside a line of code.

sections.heading: Multi-line Comments
paragraphs: CSS comments can span multiple lines.

sections.heading: HTML and CSS Comments
paragraphs: HTML comments use <!-- --> syntax.
CSS comments use /* */ syntax.
Both can be used together in HTML files.

sections.heading: CSS Errors
paragraphs: Errors in CSS can lead to unexpected behavior or styles not being applied correctly.
This section explains common CSS mistakes and how to avoid them.

sections.heading: Missing Semicolons
paragraphs: Forgetting a semicolon at the end of a property declaration can break the style rule.

sections.heading: Invalid Property Names
paragraphs: Using a property name that does not exist will be ignored by the browser.

sections.heading: Invalid Values
paragraphs: Correct properties with invalid values will not be applied.

sections.heading: Unclosed Braces
paragraphs: If a closing brace is missing, the browser may ignore the entire rule.

sections.heading: Extra Colons or Braces
paragraphs: Extra colons or misplaced braces can cause CSS rules to fail.

sections.heading: Tips to Avoid CSS Errors
paragraphs: Use a code editor with syntax highlighting.
Validate CSS using a CSS validator.
Write CSS in small sections and test frequently.

sections.heading: CSS Padding
paragraphs: The CSS padding properties are used to generate space around an element's content, inside of any defined borders.
Padding creates space inside the element, between the content and the border.

sections.heading: Padding - Individual Sides
paragraphs: CSS allows you to control padding on each side of an element.
You can set padding for top, right, bottom, and left separately.

sections.heading: Padding Values
paragraphs: Padding values can be specified in different units.
Negative values are not allowed.

sections.heading: Padding Shorthand Property
paragraphs: The padding property is a shorthand for setting all padding sides at once.

sections.heading: Four Values
paragraphs: When four values are provided, padding is applied clockwise.

sections.heading: Three Values
paragraphs: Top, left & right, and bottom padding are set.

sections.heading: Two Values
paragraphs: First value sets top & bottom padding.
Second value sets left & right padding.

sections.heading: One Value
paragraphs: All sides receive the same padding.

sections.heading: Padding and Element Width
paragraphs: Padding increases the total size of an element.
The width property does not include padding by default.

sections.heading: Padding and box-sizing
paragraphs: The box-sizing property controls how width and height are calculated.
Using border-box keeps the total width fixed.

sections.heading: CSS Height and Width
paragraphs: The CSS height and width properties are used to set the height and width of an element.
These properties define the size of the content area.
Padding, border, and margin are not included in the width and height.

paragraphs: The max-width property defines the maximum width of an element.
It prevents the element from becoming wider than the specified value.
It improves responsiveness on smaller screens.

sections.heading: CSS Box Model
paragraphs: The CSS box model is used when talking about design and layout.
Every HTML element is treated as a box.
The box model consists of content, padding, border, and margin.

sections.heading: Parts of the Box Model
paragraphs: Content – The actual content of the box such as text or images.
Padding – Clears an area around the content. It is transparent.
Border – A border that surrounds the padding and content.
Margin – Clears space outside the border and is also transparent.

sections.heading: Box Model Example
paragraphs: The following example demonstrates the CSS box model.

sections.heading: Width and Height of an Element
paragraphs: The width and height properties define only the content area.
Padding and border are added to calculate the total size.

sections.heading: Total Width Calculation
paragraphs: Total width = width + left padding + right padding + left border + right border

sections.heading: Total Height Calculation
paragraphs: Total height = height + top padding + bottom padding + top border + bottom border

sections.heading: Important Note
paragraphs: Margins are not included in the total size of the element.
Margins only affect spacing between elements.

sections.heading: CSS Animations
paragraphs: CSS allows animation of HTML elements without using JavaScript.
An animation lets an element gradually change from one style to another.
You can change as many CSS properties as you want.

sections.heading: What are CSS Animations?
paragraphs: To create animations, you must define keyframes.
Keyframes describe how the element should appear at different times.

sections.heading: Animation Name and Duration
paragraphs: The animation-name property defines the name of the animation.
The animation-duration property defines how long the animation runs.
If duration is not specified, the animation will not run.

sections.heading: CSS @keyframes Rule
paragraphs: The @keyframes rule defines the animation steps.
You can use from and to or percentage values.

sections.heading: Using Percentage Values
paragraphs: You can define multiple stages in an animation using percentages.

sections.heading: Animating Position
paragraphs: Animations can change both color and position of elements.

sections.heading: Animation Delay
paragraphs: The animation-delay property specifies when the animation should start.
Negative values start the animation as if it has already played.

sections.heading: Animation Iteration Count
paragraphs: The animation-iteration-count property specifies how many times an animation runs.
The value infinite makes the animation run forever.

exercise.question: Which property controls how many times an animation runs?

sections.heading: CSS Transitions
paragraphs: CSS transitions allow property values to change smoothly over a given duration.
They help create smooth animations without using JavaScript.

sections.heading: The CSS Transition Property
paragraphs: To create a transition effect, you must specify the property and duration.
The transition property is a shorthand for multiple transition settings.

sections.heading: Basic Transition Example
paragraphs: This example adds a transition effect to the width of a div.

sections.heading: Triggering the Transition
paragraphs: Transitions are triggered when a property value changes.
This commonly happens using pseudo-classes like :hover.

sections.heading: Multiple Property Transitions
paragraphs: Multiple CSS properties can be animated at the same time.

sections.heading: Transition Timing Function
paragraphs: The transition-timing-function controls the speed curve of the animation.

sections.heading: Transition Delay
paragraphs: The transition-delay property specifies when the transition should start.

sections.heading: Transition with Transform
paragraphs: Transitions can be combined with transforms for animation effects.

sections.heading: Shorthand Transition Property
paragraphs: All transition properties can be written using shorthand syntax.
